Dear Lauren Skinner:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately please contact the area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer at (517) 899-6024.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention: (a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to: (iii) Threats of restraint, seclusion, punishment, or
otherwise suggesting physical or emotional harm to a youth.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A has been AWOL 3 times from the facility. One of the
occasions, the youth went AWOL due to being threatened by staff.
Investigation Interviews:
On 05/13/25 a telephone call was made to Complainant. A
message was left to return the call with any additional concerns.
On 05/13/2025 an email was sent to assigned Foster Care
Worker (FCW) of Youth A advising of investigation involving youth
and agency. No additional concerns were expressed regarding
this allegation by FCW.
On 05/14/25 an in-person interview was completed with
Supervisor 1 at Wolverine. She denied threatening any youth at
the agency. She also denied seeing other staff be physically
aggressive with Youth A or other youth at the facility.
On 05/14/2025 an in-person interview occurred with Staff 1 at
Wolverine. He advised that he has worked for the agency for
almost one year. He denied having any disciplinary action in his
file and reports he is up to date on his CPI Training. He denied
seeing any staff be physically inappropriate with youth. Staff 1
stated that when youth attempt to go AWOL, staff will follow youth
and attempt to encourage them to return to campus. Staff will
also attempt to discuss consequences with the youth and advise
of the danger of the neighborhood. He denied threatening Youth
A or other youth at the facility.
On 05/20/2025 an in-person interview took place with Youth A at
Wolverine. DHHS Specialist was also present. Youth A denied
that staff have threatened him since placement at the agency. He
also denied hearing staff threaten other youth. Youth A reported
2

feeling safe at the agency, but stated he goes AWOL because he
does not like it at the agency.
On 05/20/2025 an in-person interview was held with Youth D at
Wolverine. DHHS Specialist was also present. Youth D denied
that staff are physically inappropriate with him and denied that he
has seen staff be physically inappropriate with other youth. He
denied that he or other youth have made a decision to go AWOL
due to staff being physical with them. He reports that he does not
like being placed at Wolverine but feels safe at the facility. Lastly,
Youth D denied that staff have threatened him or that he has
heard other youth threatened by staff.
On 05/20/2025 an in-person interview was completed with
Therapist at Wolverine. The DHHS specialist was also present.
Therapist denied that any of the current youth have expressed
concern to him about the staff being physically aggressive or
inappropriate with them or having been threatened.
On 05/20/2025 an in-person interview was completed with Staff 5
at Wolverine. DHHS Specialist was present also. He denied
knowledge of or hearing youth report going AWOL to escape
physical discipline or aggression of staff. He further denied
knowledge of staff making threats toward youth at the agency.
On 5/20/2025 an in-person interview of Staff 4 was completed at
Wolverine. DHHS Specialist was also present. He denied that
staff are physically aggressive with youth. He denied knowledge
of youth stating that they go AWOL due to concerns of physical
discipline by staff or because of youth fighting them. He reported
staff make appropriate attempts to try to prevent youth from going
AWOL.
On 05/20/2025 an in-person interview was completed with Staff 3
at Wolverine. DHHS Specialist was also present. Staff 3 denied
that staff are physically aggressive with youth and denied
knowledge of staff making threats toward youth.
On 05/20/2025 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 2 at
Wolverine. DHHS Specialist was also present. Staff 2 reported
that Youth A does not like redirection and has been involved in
lots of incidents since he has been at Wolverine. Staff 2 denied
that staff are physically aggressive with youth and denied that he
has heard staff making threats toward youth.
3

On 05/20/2025 an in-person interview was held with Supervisor 2
at Wolverine. DHHS Specialist was also present. She denied that
staff are aggressive with the youth and engage in any type of
physical discipline, including making threats.
On 05/20/2025 an in-person interview was held with Youth C,
Youth B and Youth G. All three youth deny that they are being
physically disciplined by staff at Wolverine. All three youth also
reported staff making attempts to discourage youth from going
AWOL and denied a desire to go AWOL from Wolverine due to
concerns of physical aggression by staff or concerns from other
youth. Youth also denied having been threatened by staff at
Wolverine.
On 05/20/2025 an attempt was made to interview Youth F at
Wolverine along with DHHS Specialist. Staff advised he just went
AWOL from the facility.
On 06/11/2025 a DHHS Case Conference was held to discuss
allegations and investigative discoveries. DHHS has confirmed
there were no findings of abuse and/or neglect.
Documents Reviewed:
Wolverine Human Services Employee Standard of Conduct
Policy: All employees of WHS are expected to conduct
themselves in accordance with the agency’s principles and values.
By accepting employment with WHS, staff have a responsibility to
WHS clients, their families, the agency, Michigan and federal law,
and to fellow employees to adhere to certain standards of conduct
and ethics. The following are prohibited client interventions:
1. Use of physical discipline inflicted in any manner.
2. WHS has a zero tolerance for rape, sexual abuse, sexual
harassment and threats to clients.
3. Use of verbal abuse, ridicule, humiliation or threat. The
above interactions constitute violation of client rights and will
not be tolerated.
Incident Reports
Incident report, Date 05/12/2025, time 6:35 pm. At 6:35 pm Youth
A ignored staff directive to stay on the playground. He then went
under the gate and began walking down Dickerson. Staff lost line
of sight and contacted supervisor.
5Incident Report, Date 05/10/2025, 6:25 pm. Police report number
2505070387. On the above date and time, Youth A was phsycally
assaulted by Youth E. Youth A became aggressive and was
4

physically restrained. After the restraint ended Youth A went
AWOL.
Incident Report, Date 05/07/2025, 6:10 pm. Police report number
2505070387. Youth A and Youth F began following Youth G out of
the gym door on Dickerson, ignoring the staff directives. The staff
followed until line of sight was lost. The youth cut through a field
at 6:25 pm. Staff 2 went to the 5th precinct and filed a Police
report.
Incident report, Date 05/11/2025, 5:10 pm. On the above date and
time, Youth A was climbing the gate in the garden to get to Youth
D and Youth B. Staff redirected the youth multiple times. Youth A
was escorted from the Garden to manage the environment. Youth
A proceeded to be verbally aggressive toward Youth D and Youth
B and staff. Youth A was redirected and ignored staff directions.
Youth A proceeded to jump the playground gate. Staff separated
youth in the playground to manage the environment. Youth A
jumped down from the gate and attempted to run into the gate at
the playground. Youth D closed the gate, and Youth A spit in his
face. A physical altercation took place, and staff intervened,
separating the clients. At 5:35 pm Youth A was upset after a
physical altercation with peers while still on high-speed charging
at staff. Youth A started beating on the front door and then
proceeded to walk towards Lenox and Charlevoix, where staff
held line of sight until it was lost at 6:04 pm. Staff stated that
Youth A was in the green house with someone in the community.
The supervisor went and redirected the client back to the site, but
Youth A refused. At 6:36, Youth A walked from the greenhouse
back on site. Youth A stated that he was hungry, was searched
and offered medical treatment, but refused. The client was
escorted inside the building for dinner.
Video Reviewed:
There was no applicable video footage relevant to youth going
AWOL due to threats by staff.
Agency Tour:
A tour of the agency was completed on May 20, 2025. There
were no areas of concern noted.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in compliance. Interviews were completed with both staff and
youth at the agency. There was no evidence to support
allegations that youth were going AWOL due to threats of physical
5

abuse. In addition, during an interview, Youth A denied being
threatened by staff while at the agency.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violations and Additional Findings of
Type Non-Compliance
Allegations Allegation #1
Wolverine staff have failed to provide supervision of youth in
program resulting in youth going AWOL and youth physically
assaulting other youth.
Allegation #2
Youth at Wolverine have “shanks” and “weapons”. Agency staff
are aware and don’t do anything about it.
Allegation #3
Staff and youth are aware of the camera blind spots at Wolverine
and try to use them to their advantage.
Allegation #4
Staff give directions to youth and encourage youth to fight each
other.
Investigation Interviews:
Allegation #1

6

7

On 05/20/2025 an in-person meeting was held with Staff 2 at
Wolverine. DHHS Specialist was also present. Staff 2 reported
8

the agency works to deter the youth from going AWOL and

On 05/20/2025 an in-person interview was held with Supervisor 2

Allegation #2

Documents Reviewed:
Wolverine Human Services Line of Sight Policy - An essential and
primary task of all program staff is to maintain adequate
supervision coverage and “Line of Sight’ of all clients when in
direct supervision of clients. Within the line of sight means that it is
possible to reasonably visually distinguish and recognize
individuals. Wolverine Human Services’ policy is to have a
minimum of one staff member maintaining “Line of Sight” with our
clients when in direct supervision. The appropriate staff to client
ratio varies between site locations and is determined by the
program and contract requirements.
Wolverine Human Services Employee Standard of Conduct
Policy- All employees of WHS are expected to conduct
themselves in accordance with the Agency's principles and
values. By accepting employment with WHS, you have a
responsibility to WHS clients, their families, the Agency, Michigan
and federal law and to fellow employees to adhere to certain
standards of conduct and ethics. The purpose of these standards
of conduct is not to restrict your rights, but rather to be certain that
you understand what conduct is expected and necessary. Nothing
in these standards of conduct is intended to prohibit or restrict
employee rights to engage in protected concerted activities.
DISCIPLINE: Employees who violate these policies are subject to
corrective action. WHS Staff shall hold the health, safety and
welfare, and the best interests of the client as a primary guide in
all decisions affecting the client. WHS Staff shall maintain
objectivity and integrity. They shall maintain respect and
support for Agency policies and procedures and take initiative
toward improving such guidelines within the specified framework
provided by WHS for such improvements. Clients shall not be
permitted to discipline other clients, except as part of an organized
therapeutic self-governing program that is conducted in
13

accordance with written policy and is supervised directly by
designated staff.
Incident Reports
Incident report, Date 04/17/2025. On 4/17/25 Youth E was noted
to have a stick. Staff asked client for the stick and Youth E
willingly handed staff the stick. Staff managed the environment
and notified shift supervisor. Staff also gave shift supervisor the
stick.
As indicated above a review of three additional incident reports
was completed. They all documented behaviors of Youth A and
his failure to follow through on staff redirection and him
subsequently going AWOL.
Analysis Allegation #1: At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency
was found to be in compliance with the licensing rule. Interviews
were completed with both staff and youth and all reported staff
provide adequate supervision in order to help prevent youth from
fighting and going AWOL.
Allegation #2: At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency
was found to be in compliance with the licensing rule. Interviews
were completed with both staff and youth and all reported staff
provide adequate supervision to prevent youth from making,
obtaining, or keeping weapons while at the facility.
Allegation #3: At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency
was found to be in compliance with the licensing rule. Interviews
were completed with both staff and youth and all reported staff do
not force youth into camera blind spots at the facility so their
actions are not recorded.
Allegation #4: At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency
was found to be in compliance with the licensing rule. Interviews
were completed with both staff and youth and all reported staff
provide adequate supervision of youth in the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established

Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention: (a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
14

pushing a youth on any part of their body.

Agency Tour:
A tour of the agency was completed. Specifically, the area where
the incident occurred (facility lounge area, hallway, and stairwell)
was viewed. The stairwell area was assessed to be an unsafe
area to engage in supine restraint of the youth. The stairwell is
composed of a landing with stairs leading up from the landing and
stairs leading down from the landing. The landing has enough
space for a person to lay down but does not allow for much
movement or staff maneuvering.
The supine restraint that occurred near the stairwell was unable to
be viewed due to the obstructed view.

Wolverine Human Services Behavior Management Policy: All
staff are to be certified in Crisis Prevention Institute Non-Violent
Crisis Intervention. Non-violent physical restrictions are only to be
used to protect clients or others from unanticipated or severely
aggressive behavior that places them at risk of violence or injury if
no intervention occurs. Interventions must be guided by a number
of factors, including safety of other clients and staff, size and
strength of client, degree of past violent behavior, whether the
client has a weapon, physical or health conditions of the client,
client's Individual Crisis Management Plan. Post-incident
debriefing must also occur.
Incident Report
Incident Report, Date 05/10/2025, 6:25 pm. Police report number
2505070387. On the above date and time, Youth A was in the
first-floor lounge talking sexually inappropriate manner. Staff
attempted redirection multiple times, however Youth A ignored the
redirection. Youth E became verbally aggressive towards Youth
A, and words were exchanged. Youth E physically assaulted
Youth A. The staff intervened by separating the youth. The staff
was escorting Youth A out of the first floor lounge, and he became
verbally aggressive, threatening staff and physically assaulting
staff. The youth was placed in a supine restraint at 6:35 pm, in
the basement stairwell off the parking lot. While in the supine
position, the youth stated the back of his head hurt and stated he
should have pulled the trigger". The speed of the youth was at
baseline. The staff disengaged at 6:38 pm. The client was offered
19

medical treatment and was taken outside for fresh air. The client
refused medical care and became high speed due to not being
able to make a call. Line of sight of the youth was lost at 6:40pm
and was last seen walking towards Mack Ave from Lenox St. The
youth officially went AWOL at 6:55 pm and the supervisor was
made aware of the incident and the AWOL.
Analysis Allegation #1:
At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in non-compliance with licensing rule 4158-1-a-ii. Review of the
video documented a push of Youth A by agency staff.
Allegation #2:
At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in compliance with licensing rule 4158-1-a-ii. Interviews were
completed with both staff and youth and there was not sufficient
evidence to support that staff attempted to strangle a youth.
Technical Assistance
Technical assistance was offered to review the restraint videos
with staff as a training tool and discuss the concerns associated
with initiating a restraint on or near stairs and in areas with limited
space.
